title: Remember the sufferings, honor the people
intro_text: More than 200,000 people from various countries in Europe were brought to the main camp of Mauthausen, Austria, and imprisoned here by the SS and the Wehrmacht. Those who were not killed immediately, mostly died within a few days, weeks or months from torture, disease, hunger and the inhuman drudgery in the quarries and tunnels. Their sufferings and deaths and the cynically indifferent cruelty of their murderers are unimaginable for us today. They were slain in the quarries and shot while fleeing, hanged and drowned, suffocated in the gas chambers and killed by petrol injections into their hearts. In order to keep the memory of the people and their sufferings alive, Seiji Kimoto has shown his exhibition "Power and Powerlessness - People, Traces, Shadows" here from September 11th to November 10th, 2006. The exhibition was organized by the Federal Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of Austria.
body_text: We are facing the ruins of the gas chambers and detention cells, the torture and murder weapons, the quarry and the abandoned sleeping quarters of the victims and feel the breath of death, which will not leave this place ever again. But the people themselves have disappeared and our memories of them are fading. Reflections of the larger contexts like the search for causes and reasons are sidelining personal memories. We try to understand and to explain, and in this process the individuals are becoming history and history is turning into a moral responsibility for the future. The sculptures "Power and Powerlessness" of sculptor and painter Seiji Kimoto from Germany are trying to reduce the gap that has arisen from the passage of time and the succession of generations. At four stations on the grounds of the former concentration camp and inside the visitor center, large human figures made of wood have been set up at the places of suffering and death of so many people, to let us remember the people in a moment of standstill, to connect to them in their despair and to pay them our last respects.
body2_text: "RU", "return undesirable" - this memo was in the files of most of the Mauthausen deportees. The ones who were brought here - at least since January 1st of 1941 - were provisioned to be quashed by heavy labor. This way, their murders were even earning the SS thousandfold profit, and sometimes they were literally forced to produce the weapons used for conducting the German war against the world. For the young and able-bodied prisoners internment meant to mine heavy granite blocks from the quarries of Mauthausen for the construction of the planned "Fuhrer city Linz", and to haul them on their backs over the 186 steep steps high "Stairs of Death" up to the camp. Many fell down to their deaths there, children and young people alike, and in the course of this often dragged others to death as well - for the amusement of the SS thugs below them. And the ones whose strength failed them to reach the top of the stairs were forced to jump into the abyss by the SS, or shot while fleeing.
body3_text: The large scale sculptures "Stairs of Death I and II" in the foyer of the memorial's visitor center depict the hopelessness of the forced laborers in the quarries, and the cruelty of their murderers, who just had to stand by and watch their victims die. And they show people who braced themselves against despair and risked their lives trying to help their fellow prisoners. The outdoor sculpture "Reminder" similarly shows a scene with a human figure trying to ward off an apparently inevitable fate by keeping up the ridge beam of a collapsing house with all her strength - a symbol of the defencelessness of the victims of the SS, the breakdown of their past lives, and the gradual disappearance of our memories of them.
body4_text: The sculptural group "Standardizing Humans" describes the situation of the detainees after their arrival at the camp, after they were forced to hand over their clothes, got shaved, were selected and marked, and received prison uniforms and prisoner's numbers - turning people like you and me into nameless victims of the arbitrariness of the SS, without identity or hope of a return to life. Like these sculptures, the three figures of the group "Load" exist in no more than two dimensions and cannot stand by themselves anymore. They represent how the structures of the camp completely determined the daily lives of the prisoners: the more than hard work, the appeals and the marching, the life behind the barbed wire and the constant hustle, the lack of sleep, illness and hunger, abandonment and the never-ending struggle for survival, the smoke in the ovens and the ever-increasing number of new arrivals.
body5_text: Without any chance of escape, they were tied to their fate like "Men at a Pile": the brutal guards, the forced labor stints consuming all forces, the endless agony of torture and humiliation. Especially the enduring inhumane work in the pits and quarries and certain death broke many of them not only physically but also mentally, as Kimoto's sculptures "The Deed" and "Splitting" depict.
body6_text: In the detention cells arbitrary humiliations and torture of prisoners were daily routine. These included lashes with the "bullwhip", punches and kicks of passing SS men, "Torstehen", a torture practice in which the victims had to stand still in the open for hours with both arms lifted, and the infamous "pole hanging", in which the victims were hung to fainting on their tied hands. The separate camp prison with more than 30 cells served the SS as a self-contained location for prolonged torture practices, including caning, and the forced standing in the dark for hours, which was used to wreck the prisoners mentally.
body7_text: The figures set up in these cells by Seiji Kimoto depict the distress and despair of the prisoners tortured here. Yet they also show their last hopes of escaping certain death, as in the sculpture "The Door". As their liberators were approaching, this hope finally became true, but only for a very small minority.
body8_text: In the cellars, this most terrible place of Mauthausen, where tens of thousands were murdered in the vilest ways, women and children, old and sick, righteous and faithful ones, time itself has come to a standstill and will not go on ever again. Today, we cannot fathom anymore the sufferings of those, who once had to pass through these rooms. We have no graves to pay them our respects. What remains is pausing to remember them at the places of their despair. We must never forget!
body9_text: In the now abandoned rooms of death, that leave us profoundly disoriented, Seiji Kimoto tries to support us with figures of people. However, the sculptures he has set up here for a limited time are not meant to be portraits, but only points of reference, giving us a chance to steady ourselves amid the horrors, and to connect with the people.
